raw_response: {"answer_index": 3, "answer_text": "Inhibition of P-glycoprotein", "confidence": 9, "reasoning": "The patient developed digitalis toxicity after verapamil was added to his regimen. Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that inhibits P-glycoprotein, a drug efflux transporter responsible for eliminating digoxin from cells and the body. When P-glycoprotein is inhibited, digoxin accumulation increases, leading to elevated serum levels and toxicity. While verapamil also inhibits CYP3A4, digoxin is not significantly metabolized by this enzyme - it is primarily eliminated unchanged by the kidneys and through P-glycoprotein-mediated transport. The clinical presentation (nausea, vomiting, palpitations, PAT with block) and elevated digoxin level (3.7 ng/mL) are classic for digoxin toxicity. There is no indication of hypokalemia or changes in intestinal absorption in this case."}
